header.title: Historisch-kritische Vorerinnerungen zu Herpentil's Schwarze Magie

central_thesis: This work presents and critically contextualizes 'Herpentil's Schwarze Magie,' a grimoire of spirit evocation. It argues that Herpentil's system, despite its title, constitutes a form of theurgic magic, focused on benevolent interactions with divine and angelic powers for constructive purposes. The text also provides a historical comparison with Kornreuther's 'Magia Ordinis' and outlines the practical mechanics for a magician to perform the rituals.

structure_content.summary: This section serves as an academic introduction to Herpentil's work, clarifying that its 'black magic' title is a misnomer; the practices are benevolent and conducted in God's name, thus aligning with theurgy. It delves into the historical context, comparing Herpentil with Kornreuther's 'Magia Ordinis,' noting their textual similarities as differing recensions of a shared tradition. Historical discrepancies, such as the 1505 publication date conflicting with the mention of Jesuits, are critically analyzed, suggesting intentional misdating to lend antiquity to the text. The commentator also asserts ownership of a transcript of Kornreuther's rare manuscript and outlines future intentions to provide a full comparison and further information on the spirits.

structure_content.chapter_title: Herpentil's Grimoire: Preface and Practical Instructions (§.1 - §.10)
structure_content.summary: This part details the practical system of Herpentil's grimoire. The preface extols magic as a profound science and warns of the dangers of improper practice, emphasizing the necessity of the magic circle for protection. Subsequent chapters provide meticulous instructions for ritual preparation: constructing the magic circle and inscribing divine names with white dove's blood; preparing a hazel wood magic wand with specific Christian inscriptions; crafting a magical hood and scapular from virgin paper; designing and empowering a spirit's sigil with raven's blood; determining optimal planetary timing; selecting a solitary ritual location; and outlining the required conduct of the solitary master or odd-numbered group during evocation. It also describes methods for coercing reluctant spirits by manipulating their sigils.

structure_content.chapter_title: Specific Evocations, Spirit Interactions, and Dismissals
structure_content.summary: This section outlines the operative phase of the ritual, beginning with a ceremonial entry formula spoken upon entering the circle. It provides specific 'Citations' for various spirits, exemplified by Fürst Amazeroth, Phisazeroth, Reymonzorackon, Amileckar, and Alenzozoff, complete with their sigils and lengthy 'barbaric names.' Instructions follow for interacting with the spirits upon their visible appearance, including confirming their identity via the magic wand and presenting the practitioner's requests. The section concludes with specific valediction formulas for dismissing the spirits and a final formula for safely dissolving the magic circle and exiting the ritual space.

The commentator concludes by reiterating the end of Herpentil's grimoire. They promise future discussions on the nature and powers of the spirits detailed within, referencing external sources like Reginald Scot's 'Discovery of Witchcraft' to elaborate on entities such as Prince Amazeroth, who is described as a duke commanding sixty legions with powers of foresight, appearing in various forms but convertible to human shape.

structure_content.chapter_title: Additional Grimoire Excerpts (from external text, pages 627-633)
structure_content.summary: This section, appearing to be from a separate grimoire due to distinct page numbering, presents alternative or complementary instructions. It details the construction of a magic circle from white linen, inscribed with specific words using the blood of a white dove. It describes a magic wand made of white-peeled wood, inscribed with a spirit's sigil using weasel blood. Prerequisites include reading three holy masses. The text also details specific incense ingredients and the wearing of Jupiter's sign on gold plate. Ritual conduct, coercion of spirits via sigil burning, and general citation and dismissal formulas for named spirits like Almischak, Ashirikas, and Amabosar are provided. It concludes with an independent general spirit citation formula and a scrying ritual using hyssop water in a glass.

key_concepts.definition: A term used in the title of Herpentil's work but explicitly reclassified by the commentator as a misnomer. The text's operations are benevolent, performed in God's name, for good purposes (e.g., knowledge, wealth, aid for the needy), and thus properly belong to theurgic magic.

The correct classification for Herpentil's system, distinguishing it from demonic or 'black' magic. It involves the ritualistic evocation and interaction with benevolent spirits and divine powers for constructive ends, emphasizing divine sanction and ethical conduct.

A fundamental protective and consecrated space, typically 9 feet in diameter, constructed from virgin paper and inscribed with specific divine names (e.g., Elohim, Adonai, Jehovah, Alpha, Omega, Om) using white dove's blood. Its primary function is to safeguard the practitioner from potentially harmful entities during evocation.

A magical tool, specifically a hazel wood wand, inscribed with the phrase 'Jesus Nazarenus Rex Judæorum' using white dove's blood. It is used by the master to direct magical energy, confirm spirit identities, and, if necessary, to coerce unwilling spirits by striking or stirring their sigils.

A unique graphical seal or symbol representing a specific spirit or entity. In Herpentil's system, sigils are drawn with coal-black raven's blood on blackened virgin paper, then displayed within the magic circle to facilitate the evocation and control of the associated spirit.

Specific invocations, often comprising lengthy strings of 'barbaric words,' divine names, and commands, recited by the master to summon particular spirits into manifestation. The precise pronunciation and form of these citations are crucial for success.

Formal commands and rituals used to safely send evoked spirits away after their task is completed or an agreement is reached. These formulas are essential to ensure the spirits depart without lingering or causing any adverse effects.

An astrological timing system where each hour of the day and night is governed by a specific planet. Operations in Herpentil's system are to be timed precisely to the New Moon, or to specific hours (e.g., those of Mercury or Venus) on designated days (Wednesday or Friday) to align with favorable celestial influences.

The central magical practice described, involving a structured ritual process to summon and interact with spirits (e.g., Fürst Amazeroth) for various beneficial purposes, such as acquiring knowledge, wealth, or assistance, all framed within a theurgic context.

practical_system.description: Herpentil's Schwarze Magie outlines a detailed ritual system for theurgic spirit evocation, designed to be benevolent and sanctioned by divine powers. The system emphasizes meticulous preparation of the practitioner and the ritual space, precise timing based on planetary hours, and the use of specific tools and incantations to summon, interact with, and dismiss spirits for various beneficial purposes (e.g., knowledge, wealth). The overall goal is to achieve desired outcomes through controlled interaction with spiritual entities.
tools: Magic Circle (virgin paper, white dove's blood, divine names)
Magic Wand (hazel wood, 'Jesus Nazarenus Rex Judæorüm' inscription, white dove's blood)
Magical Hood (virgin paper, white dove's blood, characters)
Black Robe and Scapular (virgin paper, white dove's blood, characters)
Spirit Sigils (blackened virgin paper, coal-black raven's blood)
Incense (black poppy seed, hemlock herb, coriander, celery, saffron)
rituals: Construct a magic circle of 9-foot diameter on virgin paper, inscribed with divine names (Elohim, Adonai, El Zebaoth, Agla, Jehovah, Alpha, Omega, Om) using white dove's blood.
Prepare a magic wand from hazel wood, inscribed with 'Jesus Nazarenus Rex Judæorum' using white dove's blood.
Create a magical hood (white front, black back) and a scapular, both from virgin paper and inscribed with characters using white dove's blood.
Draw the sigil of the desired spirit using coal-black raven's blood on blackened virgin paper, then hang it on a hazel stick at the circle's edge.
Prepare a specific incense mixture from unequal weights of black poppy seed, hemlock herb, coriander, celery, and saffron.
Perform operations at the New Moon, or on Wednesday/Friday during the planetary hours of Mercury or Venus.
Conduct rituals in a solitary, safe place; either indoors (with bed facing East, door/window open, only practitioners present) or outdoors in untouched natural settings.
The master must be alone or with an odd number of assistants, maintaining courage, clear speech, and silence from assistants.
Upon entering the circle, recite the entry formula: 'Harim. Karis. Astakas. Eneth. Miram. Baal. Alisa. Namutay. Arista. Kappi. Megrarath. Sagisia. Suratbakar.'
Recite the specific 'Citation' for the desired spirit (e.g., Amazeroth, Phisazeroth, Reymonzorackon, Amileckar, Alenzozoff) using their unique strings of names.

Upon a spirit's appearance in human form, confirm its identity by having it touch the magic wand. Greet it, present the task, and position specific spirits (e.g., Fürst Amazeroth) with particular phrases.
If spirits are unwilling to obey, use the magic wand to strike or stir their sigils, then heat or burn the sigils in the incense fire to compel obedience.

After the task is fulfilled, recite the specific 'Valedictio' formula for dismissal (e.g., 'Sarmisteras Labyratha Asanta Banta Kalas. Tyrantus Karisis Aristai Amazeroth Aliasi ancestherisatos ô Haram milas Helotim Arastaton.').
Upon the spirits' departure, recite the circle dissolution formula: 'Jakepta Virtutos spiritus invisibilis Horepta Kaminecka priosa labiratam Imperite band solventi.'
Recite the exit formula ('Begariston alengib Harim Beakim Hingultas mesar Kayrap Permagostus aganton Badanky Gragaim Bemtastoras argiutj.') upon leaving the circle.

relevant_quotes.text: Ich bin sehr überzeugt, daß ich Herrn Herpentil's sogenannte schwarze Magie meinen Lesern ohne Anstoß und ohne einige Gefahr Leibes oder Seelen ganz mittheilen könnte. Ohne Zweifel entsprache ich damit auch dem Wunsche derselben am besten.

Dabei muß ich bemerken, daß der Titel schwarze Magie nicht richtig gewählt ist. Denn es geschieht nichts in diesen Bogen durch den schwarzen Höllenfürsten, sondern Alles im Namen Gottes und seiner h. Engel; ferner, es wird keine Anleitung darin gegeben, Böses oder Anderen Nachtheiliges durch dämonische Hülfe zu bewirken, sondern die Geisterbeschwörungen, wovon hier allein die Rede ist, sollen nur geschehen zur Ehre Gottes und seines großen Namens...
Die Schrift gehört also ganz unter die Kategorie - nicht der schwarzen, sondern der theurgischen Magie, oder richtiger des theurgischen Aberglaubens, wovon es sich hier ausschließlich handelt.

Niemand aber, wer er auch sey, soll sich unterstehen, die hierin enthaltene Beschwörungen ohne Creiß klärlich und mit lauter Stimme zu leßen, wenn er nicht seinen Vorwiz theüer bezahlen, und sich selbsten zum Untergang seyn will.

Zu denen magischen Proben, heißt es im 1ten §., ist allezeit das erste und nothigste Stück die Formirung eines Creises, dieweilen ohne denselben Niemand vor den bösen Geistern beschüzet und sicher ist, als welche dem menschlichen Geschlecht stetiglich nachstreben.
Ohne conjuratione et spirituum concursu plane nihil effici poterit etc. etc.
Dann fährt der Vf. fort: Ein dergleichen Buch, als welches das Goldt an Werth weit übersteiget, liefere ich dir hiermit in die Hande, es ist zwar klein, enthaltet aber alle heimlichste Geheimnüße.

Sollten dieß die Jesuiten seyn, so gab es 1505 solche noch nicht. Sos nach mußte 'das Jahr, wie's bei dergleichen Schriften oft geschieht, um sie mit dem Vorurtheil des Alters,auss zustatten, absichtlich unrichtig angegeben seyn, und dann durfte Herpentil doch vielleicht am Ende weiter nichts, als eine veränderte Ausgabe von Kornreuther seyn.

critical_analysis.relevance: Herpentil's Schwarze Magie is a significant grimoire that illuminates the historical development of magical traditions in early modern Europe. Its reclassification from 'black' to 'theurgic' magic, along with its claims of Arabic origins and the integration of Christian elements, reflects the syncretic nature of occultism during this period and the efforts to legitimize spiritual practices. The text provides valuable insights into the practical aspects of Solomonic magic, emphasizing ritual precision, astrological timing, and the importance of divine names. The commentator's rigorous academic approach, including historical comparisons with Kornreuther's work and the critical assessment of dating discrepancies, enhances its scholarly value by providing a contextual framework for understanding grimoire literature.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes scholars and practitioners of Western Esotericism, historians of magic, occultists interested in grimoire traditions, and magicians seeking to understand, study, or practice a historical system of spirit evocation for benevolent ends. The explicit warnings about ritual precision and the emphasis on divine names suggest it is intended for individuals who approach magical practice with seriousness, discipline, and a structured, reverent mindset.
